questions.text: What is the most common etiological agent for acute dacryocystitis?
questions.solution:
The most common etiological agent for acute and chronic dacryocystitis is Staphylococcus aureus.

Initially, the inflammation is controlled with antibiotics and anti-inflammatory agents. Sequelae of acute dacryocystitis is a lacrimal fistula, which is treated with is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR).

questions.text: Which among the following is called malignant  glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Ciliary block glaucoma is also called as malignant glaucoma/inverse glaucoma.

It can be seen after any intraocular surgery. Forward flow of the aqueous is blocked as tips of ciliary processes rotate forward and press against lens/ intraocular lens (IOL)/anterior hyaloid of vitreous. Hence, aqueous starts collecting in the vitreous cavity. 

Clinical features :

  • Persistent flat AC
  • Negative Seidel’s test
  • Raised intraocular pressure (IOP)

Treatment

  • Atropine (malignant glaucoma also called inverse glaucoma since atropine is used), timolol, acetazolamide
  • Nd:Yag laser hyaloidotomy: making an opening in the anterior hyaloid membrane
  • Pars plana vitrectomy

Neovascular glaucoma: It is due to the presence of neovascularization over the iris-rubeosis iridis. Seen in

  • Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO): 100-day glaucoma
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy

Treatment includes retinal photocoagulation or cryotherapy and anti-VEGF agents.

questions.text: What is the most important factor influencing the focus of light rays on the retina?
questions.solution:
The anterior surface of the cornea is the most important factor influencing the focus of light rays on the retina.

The refraction of light is the maximum at the cornea, due to the curvature of the cornea and the difference between the refractive index of air and tear film. 

Refractive indices of various surfaces of the eye:

Surface  Refractive Index 
Cornea 1.376
Lens- Total  1.40
Lens- Cortex (periphery) 1.386
Lens- Nucleus  1.406 (maximum)
Aqueous Humor 1.336
Vitreous Humor 1.336

questions.text: The most common type of congenital cataract with diminished vision is ______.
questions.solution:
Lamellar or zonular cataract is the most common type of congenital cataract presenting with visual impairment.

Etiology: It may be either genetic or environmental in origin.

  • Genetic pattern is usually of familial autosomal-dominant variety
  • Environmental form is associated with:
    • Vitamin D deficiency
    • Hypocalcemia
    • Sometimes, maternal rubella infection contracted between the 7th and 8th week of gestation may also cause lamellar cataract.
  • The main mass of the lens internal and external to the zone of cataract is clear.
  • Small linear opacities like spokes of a wheel (riders) may be seen towards the equator.

 

Image: Lamellar cataract

questions.text: Complication of cataract is ______.

choices.text: Subluxation or dislocation of the lens

questions.solution:
All the options listed above are complications of cataract.

Complications of cataract:

  • Phacoanaphylactic uveitis
    • Lens protein that enters into the anterior chamber may act as an antigen and induce antigen–antibody reaction, leading to phacoanaphylactic uveitis.
  • Lens-induced glaucoma
    • Phacomorphic glaucoma
      • (Most common): seen in intumescent cataract
    • Phacolytic glaucoma: seen in hypermature cataract
    • Phacotopic glaucoma: In hypermature cataract
  • Subluxation or dislocation of the lens
    • It may occur due to degeneration of zonules in the hypermature stage.

questions.text: The anterior segment of the eye includes all except ______.
questions.solution:
The anterior segment of the eye does not include vitreous humor as it is a constituent of the posterior segment of the eye.

Anterior Segment Posterior Segment 
Cornea Vitreous humor 
Iris  Retina 
Lens  Choroid
Anterior and Posterior chambers with aqueous humor  Optic Disc

questions.text: Intermediate uveitis is also called as ________.
questions.solution:
Intermediate uveitis refers to pars planitis. It involves inflammation of the pars plana.

The uvea consists of the iris, ciliary body and choroid.  Inflammation of uveal tissue is called uveitis. It can be classified anatomically as follows: 

  • Anterior uveitis: Inflammation of iris and pars plicata, consisting of iritis, iridocyclitis and anterior cyclitis
  • Intermediate uveitis: Inflammation of pars plana (pars planitis)
  • Posterior uveitis: Inflammation of the retina with or without involvement of the retina. It includes choroiditis, chorioretinitis, retinochoroiditis and neuroretinitis. 
  • Panuveitis

Pathological classification divides uveitis into suppurative and nonsuppurative uveitis. Nonsuppurative uveitis is further classified into nongranulomatous and granulomatous uveitis. 

The image is a schematic representation of the anatomical classification of uveitis.

questions.text: What is the first sign a patient with anterior uveitis may show?
questions.solution:
Aqueous flare is the earliest sign of acute anterior uveitis.

Aqueous flare is due to the leakage of protein particles into the aqueous humor from damaged blood vessels. It is demonstrated on the slit-lamp examination. It is based on the principle of Brownian movement or Tyndall phenomenon. 

Aqueous flare is usually marked in non-granulomatous uveitis and minimal in granulomatous uveitis. The presence of cells in the anterior chamber denotes an active inflammatory process. 

The image below is a high magnification slit-beam photograph 3×1 mm in size in a darkroom showing the presence of cells and flare.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about degenerative myopia?

choices.text: It is seen in less than 6 dioptres of myopia.
It is more common in males than in females.
Myopic degeneration can lead to retinal detachment.
The condition has no racial prediliction.

questions.solution:
The statement that is true for degenerative myopia is that myopic degeneration can lead to retinal detachment.

Degenerative myopia is seen in more than 6 dioptres of myopia. It is more common in females as compared to males. The condition has a racial predilection; it is more common in Jews and Japanese people, and most cases are of genetic origin.

Changes seen in degenerative myopia are myopic crescent, rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (due to degenerative changes in the periphery of the retina with subsequent tear) and floaters (due to degenerative changes in the vitreous).

questions.text: Ascorbate and alpha-tocopherol are maintained in the lens in the reduced state by _______.
questions.solution:
Ascorbate and alpha-tocopherol are maintained in the lens in the reduced, functional state by glutathione.

Glutathione is present in high concentrations in the lens, particularly in the epithelial layer. One of its key functions is to maintain protein thiols in their reduced state, which preserves the lens transparency by preventing the formation of high molecular weight crystalline aggregates and protects the lens from oxidative stress. 

The lens is highly prone to photochemical reactions from continuous exposure to ultraviolet rays (295–400 nm), leading to reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation. Its defence relies heavily on superoxide dismutase, ascorbate, catalase and glutathione peroxidase. 

With ageing or cataracts, levels of glutathione and ascorbic acid (in reduced form) significantly decrease.

questions.text: A middle aged male presents with recurrent oral ulcers and ulcers over his scrotum. He also has pain and redness of both his eyes. A positive pathergy test is noted. What is the HLA association of the disease this patient is most likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
Recurrent oral ulcers, ulcers over his scrotum with binocular pain and redness and a positive pathergy test point to a diagnosis of Behcet's disease. HLA B5 (HLA B51) is associated with Behcet's disease.

Behcet's disease is a systemic vasculitis that can cause recurrent oral ulcers, genital ulcers, skin lesions and ocular inflammation. Pathergy test is usually positive. Ocular inflammation occurs in about 70% of patients and tends to be more severe in men. A classical presentation is relapsing/remitting acute onset panuveitis with retinal vasculitis which resolves spontaneously even without treatment. It is usually bilateral and non-granulomatous. Patients present with a transient mobile hypopyon in a relatively white eye. They may develop visual impairment if retinal vascular disease (vasculitis and occlusion) occurs. 

Other options:

Option A: HLA-B27 is associated with Reiter's syndrome.

Option B: HLA DR1 and HLA-DR4 are associated with Vogt–Koyanagi–Haradas disease. 

Option D: HLA Bw54 is associated with Possner–Scholssman syndrome. 

Note: The association between HLA-A29 and birdshot retinochoroidopathy is the most consistent of any medical disorder. Approximately 95% of patients with birdshot retinochoroidopathy are HLA-A29–positive.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not pass through the superior orbital fissure?
questions.solution:
The optic nerve (2nd cranial nerve) passes through the optic canal, not the superior orbital fissure.

Anatomy of the orbit

Orbit is a pear-shaped cavity, the stalk of which is the optic canal. The volume of the orbit is 30 cc.

Walls of the orbit Bones forming them
Roof

Lesser wing of the sphenoid

The orbital plate of the frontal bone
Lateral wall (strongest wall)

Greater wing of the sphenoid

Zygomatic bone
Floor (most frequently fractured wall)

Zygomatic bone

Maxillary bone

Palatine bone
Medial wall (thinnest wall)

Maxillary bone

Lacrimal bone

Ethmoid bone

Sphenoid bone


The image below shows the bones forming the orbit.

The inferior orbital fissure lies between the greater wing of the sphenoid and the maxilla, connecting the orbit to the pterygopalatine and infratemporal fossae. Through it run the maxillary nerve, the zygomatic nerve, and branches of the pterygopalatine ganglion, as well as the inferior ophthalmic vein.

Related Pearl: Superior orbital fissure

Structures passing through the Superior orbital fissure

Above the common tendinous ring: LFT (Superolateral compartment)

  • Lacrimal nerve
  • Frontal nerve
  • Trochlear nerve
  • Superior opthalmic vein

Within the common tendinous ring: BAN (Intermediate compartment)

  • Both divisions of oculomotor nerve
  • Abducens nerve
  • Nasociliary nerve

Below the common tendinous ring (Inferomedial compartment)

  • Inferior ophthalmic vein

questions.text: In which surgery would you use the instrument shown below?
questions.solution: The image shows a Ziegler knife, which is used to open the lens capsule and aspirate the lens material in congenital cataract surgeries.

questions.text: Which optical instrument provides an inverted and reversed image of the retina?

choices.text: Goldmann contact lens and slit lamp

questions.solution:
An indirect ophthalmoscope produces a real, inverted and laterally reversed image of the fundus.

All the other instruments mentioned including direct ophthalmoscope, Hruby lens and Goldman contact lens produce a virtual and erect image of the fundus.

questions.text: A small kid is brought for examination due to difficulty reading from the board at school. Visual acuity was 20/60 in both eyes. His vision got corrected with concave lens spectacles. Which of the following is the most common cause of this refractive error?

choices.text: Increased anteroposterior diameter of the eye ball
Increase in the refractive index of lens

questions.solution:
Poor vision for distance (difficulty reading from board) that is corrected with concave lens spectacles suggest that the child has myopia. The most common cause of myopia (shortsightedness) is increased anteroposterior length of the eyeball.

Myopia is a type of refractive error seen when the parallel rays of light from infinity are focused in front of the retina when accomodation is at rest.

Related Pearl: Causes of Myopia

Myopia

Etiology

Axial myopia

(Most common)

Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball.

Curvatural myopia

Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both

Positional myopia

Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye

Index myopia

Increase in the refractive index of crystalline lens

Nocturnal myopia

Due to spherical aberration and accomodation

questions.text: What does the given fundoscopic picture suggest?
questions.solution:
The given fundoscopic image clearly depicts cupping, thinning of the neuroretinal rim, and nasal shifting of vessels. This are characteristic of glaucomatous optic atrophy. 

Related Pearl: Classification of optic atrophy

  • Simple optic atrophy: (Primary) Image below
    • Pathology lies in portion of optic nerve behind lamina cribrosa.
    • Causes are multiple sclerosis, neurosyphilis, and traumatic optic neuropathy.
    • Well defined disc margin and chalky white in color.

Post-neuritic optic atrophy: (Secondary)

  • Occurs after disc edema.
  • Causes are Papillitis and papilledema
  • Blurred disc margin and dirty white in color
  • Consecutive optic atrophy
    • Extensive pathology of retina.
    • Causes are retinitis pigmentosa and any cause of diffuse chorioretinitis
    • Well defined disc margin and pale waxy disc.
  • Glaucomatous optic atrophy/Cavernous optic atrophy:
    • 100% cupping
    • Bayonetting of vessels
    • Laminar dot sign

questions.text: The most common nerve involved in herpes zoster ophthalmicus is ______.
questions.solution:
• The most common nerve involved in herpes zoster ophthalmicus (HZO) is the frontal nerve, which is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve.
  • Herpes zoster ophthalmicus is an acute infection of the Gasserian ganglion of the fifth cranial nerve by the varicella-zoster virus.

Note:

Most specific nerve involved in HZO is the nasociliary nerve (Because patients with nasocilliary nerve involvement (Hutchinson’s sign) indicates that they will develop corneal involvement although it is not 100% true.

questions.text: What is the Stiles-Crawford effect?

choices.text: Cutting off of the peripheral rays by the iris
High refractive index of the core of nucleus of the lens than that of the peripheral cortex
Low sensitivity of the peripheral retina
More sensitivity of the retina to perpendicular rays than the oblique rays

questions.solution:
The Stiles–Crawford effect refers to the greater sensitivity of the retina to perpendicular rays than the oblique rays. It is one of the natural mechanisms that decrease aberration in the eye. The rays of light that enter through the center of the pupil have higher sensitivity as compared to those entering from the periphery of the pupil.  

Natural mechanisms that decrease aberrations in the human eye:

  • Cutting-off of the peripheral rays by the iris
  • The high refractive index of the core of the nucleus of the lens than that of the peripheral cortex
  • Low sensitivity of the peripheral retina
  • Stiles–Crawford effect

questions.text: Mr. Hamid, a 45-year-old, known case of Crohn's disease, complains of tearing and photophobia in his right eye. On examination, his eye appears as shown. You note from his file that he had presented with similar complaints 4 months back and 3 months prior to that as well. What is the most common complication of the eye complaints he has?
questions.solution:
The image showing keratic precipitates, an irregular pupil, and his complaints suggest a diagnosis of anterior uveitis. He has had multiple episodes, with a period of >3 months between each, suggesting recurrent anterior uveitis. The most common complication of recurrent anterior uveitis is complicated cataract.

The most common complication of anterior uveitis is glaucoma (secondary open-angle > secondary angle-closure glaucoma)

Other complications of anterior uveitis:

  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Exudative retinal detachment (chronic anterior and posterior uveitis)
  • Vitreous hemorrhage

 Recurrent anterior uveitis is associated with autoimmune conditions like Crohn's disease, Behcet's disease, ankylosing spondylitis, etc.

questions.text: Topical retinoic acid may be used in the management of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Topical retinoic acid is used to treat ocular-surface squamous neoplasia (OSSN). It is the most common malignancy of the conjunctiva.

Indications of topical retinoic acid:

  • Manage severe, resistant, dry eye
  • Enhance wound healing in the ocular surface 
  • Decrease the ocular surface keratinization that occurs with limbal stem-cell deficiency

questions.text: A 6-month-old girl was brought by her worried parents due to a swelling on the eyelid as shown below. They were told by a local village doctor that the swelling will disappear on its own but recently it has been increasing rapidly. What would be the most likely management of this baby's condition?

choices.text: Treatment with intralesional steroids at 2 years of age

questions.solution:
The history and image are suggestive of capillary hemangioma involving the left upper lid and periocular region causing severe mechanical ptosis. Immediate management with oral propranolol is the treatment of choice in this case.

The ptosis is so severe that it obstructs the pupillary area (visual axis) with the risk of sensory deprivation amblyopia.  This warrants immediate treatment to reduce the bulk of the tumor.

Capillary hemangioma regresses spontaneously very often. It may be managed by oral propranolol, oral prednisolone, or intralesional steroid.

Indications for treatment of patients with capillary hemangioma with pharmacologic therapy are:

  • Visual symptoms (amblyopia, astigmatism, occlusion, strabismus)
  • Cosmesis
  • Optic nerve compression
  • Exposure keratopathy

questions.text: The strongest HLA association to ocular disease is in which condition given below?
questions.solution: The association between HLA-A29 and birdshot retinochoroidopathy is the most consistent of any medical disorder. Approximately 95% of patients with birdshot retinochoroidopathy are HLA-A29–positive.

questions.text: A patient presented with painless decrease in vision and metamorphopsia. Fundus examination revealed the lesion shown in the image. What is the expected finding on angiography?
questions.solution:
The clinical vigenette is of a patient presenting with painless dimunition of vision and metamorphopsia with the right fundus showing choroidal melanoma superotemporal to the optic disc and involving the macula.

In this patient a “Double circulation” pattern consisting of an internal circulation within the lesion and the normal vascularity of the overlying retina will be seen on angiography.

Although collar stud(Option C) appearance is pathagnomic for choroidal melanoma, it can be seen on B-scan and not on angiography. 

Choroidal melanoma is a primary intraocular malignancy in adults that peaks around 60 years of age.

Symptoms include a range of visual disturbances such as painless decrease in vision and metamorphosia when macula is involved.

Other features of Choroidal melanoma includes:

  • A solitary elevated subretinal grey-brown dome shaped mass
  • Clumps of orange pigment are common over the mass
  • Collar stud appearance on B-scan (option C): It is pathagnomic of choridal melanoma. It is seen if the tumour breaks through the Bruch's membrane into the subretinal space .
  • Associated haemorrhage

Smoke stack pattern (option A) and ink blot (option B) pattern is seen on FFA in central serous retinopathy (CSR).

CSR is the spontaneous serous detachment of the sensory neuroretina in the foveal region with or without retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) detachment.

This occurs due Choroidal vascular hyperpermeability.

On FFA it is initially seen as an ink-blot pattern or smoke stack pattern of hyperfluorescence which then spreads to take the configuration of mushroom or umbrella pattern.

The below given images depict the smoke stack pattern and mushroom pattern respectively

questions.text: In patients with a long-standing history of Crohn's disease, which of the following ocular complications is the most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
The most common ocular manifestation of Crohn’s disease is episcleritis.

Uveitis is associated with both Ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.

questions.text: An ophthalmologist tests a particular phenomenon using the instrument shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the same?

choices.text: The phenomenon is a physiological one
Frontal lobe controls the slow pursuit movement
Reversal of optokinetic nystagmus, in congenital motor nystagmus

questions.solution:
The given image shows an optokinetic drum used to elicit optokinetic nystagmus (OKN). The parieto-occipital lobe controls the slow pursuit component, whereas the frontal lobes control the saccadic component.

OKN is normal physiological nystagmus in response to motion/continuously moving objects. It occurs in response to a repetitive visual stimulus moved across the visual field. The slow phase occurs in the direction of the moving stimulus; the fast phase occurs as a saccadic refixation movement in the opposite direction. In patients with congenital motor nystagmus, a reversal of the OKN response may occur. An OKN response elicited in a person who feigns visual loss indicates that visual input is present and is a malingerer.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the innervation of extraocular muscles is false?

choices.text: The levator palpebrae is innervated by a fused central nucleus
The superior oblique is innervated by the ipsilateral IV nucleus
The inferior oblique is innervated by the ipsilateral III nucleus
The superior rectus is innervated by the contralateral III nucleus

questions.solution:
The superior oblique is innervated by contralateral trochlear (IV cranial nerve) nucleus.

The nuclei controlling the superior rectus and superior oblique muscles have crossed projections.

questions.text: A researcher is studying mutations in the rhodopsin gene which are responsible for some forms of autosomal dominant retinitis pigmentosa. On which chromosome is this gene located?
questions.solution:
The gene for rhodopsin is located at 3q22.1

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common. Among the hereditary types, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis.

The presenting feature is night blindness.

Investigations:

  • Perimetry - the initial stage will have ring scotoma, which further develops into tunnel vision.
  • Electroretinography - reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.

Retinitis pigmentosa is a condition with no cure. There are drugs used to slow down the progression such as acetazolamide for concomitant cystoid macular edema. Recently, vitamin A has been recommended, although the efficacy has not been established.

questions.text: A man with history of hypertension and loss of vision in the left eye has the following fundoscopy findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image above demonstrates characteristic flame-shaped hemorrhages, localized to the superotemporal sector of the retina. The image, along with loss of vision and history of hypertension, points to a diagnosis of branched retinal vein occlusion (BRVO), specifically affecting the superotemporal branch of the retinal vein.

Occlusion of a single branch of the retinal vein leads to branched retinal vein occlusion. This occlusion leads to impaired venous drainage, resulting in the accumulation of blood within the retina. The visual defect in BRVO tends to be partial. 

Note: The different types of retinal vascular obstructions are branched retinal vein obstruction (BRVO), central retinal vein obstruction (CRVO), branched retinal artery obstruction (BRAO) and central retinal artery obstruction (CRAO). Retinal vein occlusion (RVO) is the second most common retinal vascular disorder after diabetic retinopathy.

In CRVO, tortuosity and engorgement of all branches of the central retinal vein are seen, affecting all quadrants of the retina.

questions.text: Which of the following findings on a fundus examination would suggest severe non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy?

choices.text: Significant venous beading in any of the 4 quadrants

questions.solution:
Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants is a feature of severe NPDR.

Note: Macular star is a feature of malignant hypertensive retinopathy.

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman finally decides to get glasses, about thirty years after she actually needed them, and goes to an optometrist for an eyeglass prescription. Her eye examination reveals some unexpected findings. The pupils were small. When a pen-light is shone on to her eyes, neither pupil contracts. However, when the optometrist brings his fingers towards her face, both pupils constrict dramatically. What is the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation of bilateral small irregular pupils with light-near dissociation suggests a diagnosis of Argyll Robertson pupil.

Features of Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP):

  • Accommodation Reflex Present (ARP)
  • Light Reflex absent
  • Constricted pupil
  • An example of light near dissocation.
  • Seen in neurosyphilis

Option A: Anisocoria is when the pupils are not of the same size.

Option B: Adie's tonic pupil

  • Light reflex absent or sluggish.
  • Near reflex: Slow and tonic
  • Pupil is larger
  • Constricts with weak pilocarpine.

Option C: Ophthalmoplegia interna

  • Dilated paralyzed pupil
  • Does not respond to light or accommodation

questions.text: The zone of the lens nucleus that does not form Y-shaped sutures is ____.
questions.solution:
The primary fibers in the embryonic nucleus of the lens do not form Y-shaped sutures.

 Types of lens nucleus and their age of development: 

  • Embryonic nucleus: Innermost nucleus formed at around 1–3 months of gestation
  • Fetal nucleus: From 3 months of gestation till birth
  • Infantile nucleus: From birth to puberty
  • Adult nucleus

As lens fibers grow anteriorly and posteriorly, a pattern emerges where the ends of the fibers meet. These patterns of cell association are known as sutures. 

Y-shaped sutures are recognizable at about 8 weeks of gestation.

Image: Erect Y-suture appearing anteriorly and an inverted Y-suture posteriorly

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presented with progressive diminution of vision, headache, and unsteadiness of gait. A comprehensive clinical evaluation revealed coarse, left-beating nystagmus with leftward gaze and a fine primary-position right-beating nystagmus which increased on rightward gaze, consistent with Brun's nystagmus. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Bruns nystagmus is an unusual type of bilateral nystagmus most commonly occurring in patients with cerebellopontine angle tumors.

It is caused by the combination of slow, large-amplitude nystagmus (gaze paretic nystagmus) when looking towards the side of the lesion, and rapid, small amplitude nystagmus (vestibular nystagmus) when looking away from the side of the lesion. 

Option A- Cerebellar lesions and Arnold–Chiari malformation: downbeat nystagmus

Options C and D- Arnold–Chiari malformation and demyelination syndromes: periodic alternating nystagmus (left beating nystagmus->null phase->right beating nystagmus->null phase).

questions.text: Embryonic development of ciliary muscles is from _______.
questions.solution:
Embryonic development of ciliary muscles is from the neural crest.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged after removing  the drain tube on the first postoperative day. On day three, the patient came back to the hospital and was febrile. On ultrasound examination, there was a 5 x 5 cm collection in the subhepatic space. Next best step is ______.

choices.text: To give oral antibiotics since the given accumulation is normal
To re-explore the wound and insert a T-tube

questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests  a bile duct injury following laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The next best step after imaging would be to control inflammation by

  • Drainage of fluid collections (Pigtail insertion and drainage) and
  • Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Bile duct injury

  • Usually is manifested in the postoperative period
  • Clinical features
    • Fever
    • Increasing abdominal pain
    • Jaundice
    • Bile leakage from an incision

Diagnosis

Imaging: Ultrasonography

  • To assess for a fluid collection and to evaluate the biliary tree 

Treatment Strategy

  • Control of infection, limiting inflammation
    • Percutaneous drainage of periportal fluid collections
    • Parenteral antibiotics
  • Clear and thorough delineation of entire biliary anatomy
    • Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) or percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC)
    • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), especially if cystic-duct stump leak is suspected
  • Reestablishment of biliary-enteric continuity (surgery)
    1. Tension-free, mucosa-to-mucosa anastomosis
    2. Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not presents as pulsatile proptosis?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, hemangioma will not present with pulsatile proptosis.

Causes of pulsatile proptosis:

  • Pulsating vascular lesions:
    • Caroticocavernous fistula- most common
    • Saccular aneurysm of ophthalmic artery
  • Transmitted cerebral pulsations in conditions with a deficient orbital roof:
    • Congenital meningocele/meningoencephalocele
    • Neurofibromatosis

questions.text: Ophthalmoplegic migraine clinically presents as ___________.

choices.text: Headache with irreversible loss of optic nerve function
Headache associated with recurrent third nerve palsy
Headache associated with third, fourth, and sixth nerve palsy

questions.solution:
Ophthalmoplegic migraine refers to headache associated with third, fourth, and sixth nerve palsy.

Ophthalmoplegic migraine almost always involves the third nerve. Rare cases of sixth nerve involvement, and even rarer cases that involve the fourth nerve, have also been reported.

Clinical criteria for the diagnosis of ophthalmoplegic migraine include:

  • A prior history of typical common or classic migraine headaches
  • Ophthalmoplegia that occurs during (or, rarely, just before) an established migraine attack
  • Exclusion of other reasonable causes by clinical and radiological studies

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV-positive lady with CD4+ count of 35/μL presented with decreased visual acuity and floaters. On fundus examination, there were dense, white areas of retinal necrosis with interspersed areas of retinal hemorrhage. What is the most rapid and accurate method to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Viral nucleic acid detection in intraocular fluid
Viral antibody detection in blood by ELISA

questions.solution:
An HIV-positive patient with CD4+ count of 35/μL presenting with decreased visual acuity, floaters and pizza pie retinitis (dense, white areas of retinal necrosis with interspersed areas of retinal hemorrhage) likely has CMV retinitis. The most rapid and accurate method to diagnose cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis is viral nucleic acid detection in the intraocular fluid.

CMV retinitis is an opportunistic infection seen in HIV patients with a CD4+ count less than 50/μL. Patients present with  reduced vision due to macular involvement and floaters due to vitritis. One eye is usually affected initially. Retinitis is seen. Frosted branch angiitis (FBA), which is marked vascular sheathing that occurs in about 6% patients, may be seen. Cataract is common late-stage manifestation of CMV retinitis. 

Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is the mainstay of management, restoring the patient’s innate ability to suppress CMV activity. Valganciclovir is a prodrug of ganciclovir that is taken orally. Ganciclovir slow-release intravitreal implant can also be used. 

Screening of patients with low CD4+ counts:

  • 3-monthly, if <50/μl
  • 6-monthly, if  50–100/μl
  • Yearly, if >100/μl

CMV retinitis is one of the most serious ocular complications in immune-suppressed individuals and can lead to irreversible vision loss. Patients with CD4 counts <50 cells/mm3 should be seen at least every 3 months to screen for CMV retinitis, as active retinitis is typically asymptomatic.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common clinical presentation of retinoblastoma?
questions.solution:
The most common clinical presentation of retinoblastoma is leukocoria plus strabismus.

Clinical features of retinoblastoma:

  • Present within the first two years of life
  • Leukocoria 
  • Strabismus
  • Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma
  • Orbital inflammation mimicking orbital or pre-septal cellulitis.
  • Orbital invasion or visible extraocular growth may occur in neglected cases.
  • Metastatic disease involving regional lymph nodes and the brain before the detection of ocular involvement is rare.

Signs:

  • An intraretinal tumor is a homogeneous, dome-shaped white lesion that becomes irregular, often with white flecks of calcification.
  • An endophytic tumor projects into the vitreous as a white mass that may "seed" into the gel.
  • An exophytic tumor forms multilobular subretinal white masses and causes an overlying retinal detachment.

Investigations:

  • Red reflex testing with a direct ophthalmoscope is a simple screening test for leukocoria.
  • Dilated fundus examination using indirect ophthalmoscope
  • MRI of the orbit + brain

questions.text: What is the laser used in posterior capsulotomy and its principle?
questions.solution:
The laser used in posterior capsulotomy is Nd:YAG laser (1064 nm) whose principle is photodisruption. The plasma produced at the laser target expands and disrupts the tissues creating an opening.

Posterior capsular opacification is managed by creating an opening on the posterior capsule along the visual axis, a procedure called posterior capsulotomy.

Option D: Double frequency Nd:YAG laser is used in posterior segment photocoagulation.

questions.text: An eleven-year-old girl presented with a history of squint and poor vision. She had visual acuities of 6/24 and counting fingers in her right and left eyes respectively. There was a left hypotropia in the primary position of gaze with associated marked restriction of elevation in adduction and a positive forced duction test. A diagnosis of Brown syndrome was made. The pathology involves which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
Brown syndrome occurs due to mechanical restriction caused by a congenitally tight superior oblique sheath or by the impaired movement of the superior oblique tendon through the trochlea. It may be acquired in some cases.

Contracture of the superior oblique leads to restriction of its antagonistic muscle, the inferior oblique and that is why the patient presents with absence of elevation in adduction.

questions.text: The following image shows the picture of the fundus in a patient taken 48 hours after sustaining severe head trauma. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows multiple cotton wool spots around the disc. This is Purtschers' retinopathy, which is classically associated with severe head injury. 

It is also seen in pancreatitis and chest trauma due to fat/air embolism. Ophthalmoscopy reveals multiple, variably sized cotton-wool spots and intraretinal hemorrhages around the optic nerve. There is no effective treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following range defines moderate myopia?
questions.solution:
Moderate myopia is defined when the refractive error is between -3D and -6D. 

Note: Myopia according to age of onset:

  • Congenital: Present at birth
  • Youth onset: 2–20 years of age
  • Early adult onset: 20–40 years of age
  • Late adult onset: >40 years of age

Related Pearl: Grading of Myopia

American Optometric Association (AOA) Grading of Myopia:

  • Low myopia, when the error is < –3D.
  • Moderate myopia, when the error is between -3D to -6D.
  • High myopia, when the error is > –6D.

questions.text: The most common type of scleritis is ______.
questions.solution:
Non-necrotizing anterior scleritis is the most common type of scleritis. 

Scleritis can be classified into anterior and posterior scleritis. Anterior scleritis affects the sclera in front of the equator, while posterior scleritis affects the sclera behind the equator of the eye. Anterior scleritis is further classified into the following types:

  1. Non-necrotizing
    1. Diffuse: The most common variety
    2. Nodular: Scleral nodules are present. Annular scleritis is a variant in which the scleral nodules are arranged in a ring around the limbus. 
  2. Necrotizing
    1. With inflammation
    2. Without inflammation: Also known as scleromalacia perforans. It is seen in elderly females with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis.

The image below shows anterior nodular scleritis.

questions.text: Which of the following forms the third-order neurons in the visual pathway?
questions.solution:
Third-order neurons in the visual pathway are the ganglion cells.

The afferent neuronal impulses are carried in the following manner:

Photoreceptors (I) ⇒ Bipolar cells (II) ⇒ Ganglion cells (III) ⇒ Lateral geniculate body (IV).

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic for a change of her presbyopic glasses. This is the third time that she is coming in 2 months. What is the likely underlying diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Frequent changes in presbyopic glasses in this patient is a symptom of open-angle glaucoma (OAG).

This is due to increasing accommodative failure as a result of constant pressure on the ciliary muscle and nerve supply.

In intumescent cataracts, patients report difficulty with distance vision and frequent change of spectacle prescription. However, it is not associated with frequent changes of presbyopic glasses.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman came for an eye exam due to a gritty sensation that has been causing her a lot of discomfort. On examination, Rose Bengal staining is positive. She is diagnosed with keratoconjunctivitis sicca. Which of the following layer of the tear film is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Keratoconjunctivitis sicca is due to the deficiency of the aqueous layer of the tear film.

In keratoconjunctivitis sicca, patients present with irritation and foreign body sensation. Marginal tear strip is reduced. The conjunctiva become dry and lustreless with positive Rose Bengal staining. Causes of keratoconjunctivitis sicca:

  • Sjogren's syndrome (primary keratoconjunctivitis sicca)
  • Non-Sjogren's keratoconjunctivitis sicca
    • Primary age-related hyposecretion (most common)
    • Lacrimal gland deficiencies - congenital, infiltration by tumors or sarcoidosis, surgical removal
    • Lacrimal gland duct obstruction - old trachoma, burns,  SJS
    • Reflex hyposecretion (neurogenic causes) - Parkinson disease, 7th nerve palsy, reflex sensory block

Hyperosmolarity of the tear film in dry eye disease leads to a cascade of signaling events that releases inflammatory mediators and leads to damage to the ocular surface which may further decrease tear film stability, leading to self-perpetuation of the disease in a "vicious circle".

Related Pearl: Layers of the Tear Film

Lipid layer

  • Outermost layer
  • Secreted by the meibomian, Zeis glands
  • Prevents evaporation of tears

Aqueous layer

  • Middle layer
  • Secreted by the lacrimal and accessory lacrimal glands
  • Provides lubrication

Mucin layer  

  • Innermost layer
  • Secreted by the goblet cells of the conjunctiva
  • Help in spreading the tear film over the ocular surface

The maximum density of the goblet cells is seen on the nasal bulbar conjunctiva.

questions.text: The normal extent of the visual field superiorly is ________.
questions.solution:
The extent of visual field superiorly is 50°

Normal extent of the visual field: 

  • Temporal: 90°/100°
  • Inferiorly: 70°
  • Nasal: 60°
  • Superiorly: 50°

Note: According to Parson's 22nd Ed., Page no. 101, the visual field extends 60o superiorly. However, most journals and other standard textbooks consider the answer to be 50o. Hence, we choose 50o as the most appropriate answer.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries?
questions.solution:
Chlamydia is at present the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatarum in developed countries.

Ophthalmia neonatarum also called neonatal conjunctivitis is inflammation of the conjunctiva occurring in an infant <30 days after birth.It should be ruled out in any infant having discharge or watering within the first week of birth.

Causes include:

  1. Chlamydia(Option A): neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis caused by serotypes D-K is at present the most common cause in developed countries. 
  2. Gonorrhoea(Option B): effective prophylaxis against gonococcal infection and its subsequent decline has almost eliminated it's incidence in developed countries.
  3. Staphylococcus aureus(Option D), Haemophilus species, Streptococcus haemolyticus, and Streptococcus pneumoniae are other less commonly seen causes of ophthalmia neonatarum
  4. Herpes simplex ophthalmia neonatrum rarely occurs and is caused by Herpes simplex type 2 virus from the mother.
  5. Chemical conjunctivitis(Option C) is caused by the application of prophylactic antibiotics or silver nitrate at the time of birth. 
Time of presentation Causative agent
Within 48 h Chemical, Gonorrhoea
48–72 h

Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae
5–7 days Herpes simplex II
>1 week Chlamydia


Prophylactic treatment: 1% tetracycline or erythromycin eye ointment is applied to the eyes, if the mother is suspected to have gonococcal or chlamydia infection.

Curative treatment: 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis (D– K)- Erythromycin eye ointment
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae- Ceftriaxone injection, gentamicin drops, bacitracin eye ointment

The below image shows an infant presenting with ophthalmia neonatarum.

questions.text: You are evaluating a case of strabismus in a 3-year-old child. Which of the following tests would you use to assess binocular single vision?
questions.solution:
Binocular single vision is tested by a synoptophore.

Binocular single vision is the state of simultaneous vision, which is achieved by the coordinated use of both eyes so that separate and slightly dissimilar images arising in each eye are appreciated as a single image by the process of fusion.

The synoptophore compensates for the angle of squint and allows stimuli to be presented to both eyes simultaneously. It can thus be used to investigate the potential for binocular function in the presence of a manifest squint and is of particular value in assessing young children (from age 3 years), who generally find the test process enjoyable. It can also detect suppression.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiencies would you suspect in a patient with acute retrobulbar neuritis?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B1 deficiency can cause acute retrobulbar neuritis.

Nutritional optic neuropathy is characterized by bilateral, symmetric, cecocentral scotomas and disturbance of color vision. Fundus morphology is usually normal. 

Deficiencies in the following vitamins are primarily responsible for the damage caused to the optic nerve: B1 (thiamine), B6 (pyridoxine), B9 (folic acid), and B12 (cobalamin). These vitamins are cofactors for many metabolic reactions and their deficiency leads to toxic byproduct accumulation within cells, which inhibits the electron transport chain and depresses mitochondrial function. Depletion of ATP leads to nerve dysfunction and eventual nerve death.

Chronic alcohol abuse is a commonly associated risk factor and a cause of malnourishment.  

Related Pearl: Ophthalmic manifestation in vitamin deficiency

Vitamin deficiency Ophthalmic manifestation
A
  • Xerophthalmia
B1
  • Corneal anesthesia
  • Conjunctival and corneal dystrophy
  • Acute retrobulbar neuritis
B2
  • Photophobia
  • Burning sensation
  • Vascularization of the cornea
B12
  • Bilateral centrocecal scotoma
C
  • Hemorrhage in eye
D
  • Zonular cataract
  • Papilledema

questions.text: A lady is referred from the medicine department for an eye exam due to gritty sensation in her eyes. She is a known case of hyperthyroidism. Her ophthalmic examination shows the following finding along with the inability to look up. Which of the following is not a treatment modality for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of grittiness in the eyes (due to ocular dryness), hyperthyroidism and the image showing exophthalmos are suggestive of Graves ophthalmopathy.

Beta-blockers are not indicated in the treatment of graves ophthalmopathy, however, they are used in the symptomatic management of hyperthyroidism.

Treatment of thyroid ophthalmopathy:

(A) Non-surgical management

  • Systemic steroids- These form the mainstay of the treatment. Oral, intravenous or orbital steroid injections can be used depending upon patient indications. (Option B)
  • Radiotherapy- Orbital radiation given in a dose of 2000 rads over 10-14 days can be considered in cases where steroids are ineffective/ contraindicated. It is contraindicated in cases of extensive thyroid eye disease as it can worsen it. (Option A)
  • Teprotumumab (IGF-1R inhibitor)- is used for persistent, corticosteroid-resistant disease or non-response to first-line treatment. It is effective in reducing proptosis and clinical activity in patients.

(B) Surgical management:

  • Orbital decompression- It may be required for an acutely progressive optic neuropathy and/or exposure keratitis, in patients not responding to aggressive steroid therapy. (Option D)
  • Extraocular muscle surgery- Inferior rectus recession is the most commonly performed surgery. These should be performed after the orbital decompression since decompression may alter extraocular motility. Extraocular muscle surgery helps in achieving a binocular single vision in the primary gaze and reading position.
  • Eyelid surgery- This is done to correct eyelid retraction. Various surgeries that can be performed are mullerectomy, levator recession/ disinsertion, scleral grafts with LPS recession, recession of lower eyelid retractors, and blepharoplasty.

questions.text: Moll glands are examples of _______
questions.solution:
Moll glands are examples of apocrine sweat gland.

Moll glands are present in the eyelid. They are a type of modified apocrine sweat glands opening either into a lash follicle or directly onto the anterior lid margin between the lashes.

Zeis glands are a type of modified sebaceous glands associated with lash follicles. Meibomian glands are modified sebaceous glands found in the tarsal plates.

questions.text: Malignant glaucoma is seen in __________.
questions.solution:
Malignant glaucoma is seen after intra-ocular surgery (usually after trabeculectomy).

Ciliary block glaucoma is also called malignant glaucoma/inverse glaucoma. It can be seen after any intraocular surgery. Forward flow of the aqueous is blocked as tips of ciliary processes rotate forward and press against the lens/intraocular lens (IOL)/anterior hyaloid of the vitreous. Hence, aqueous humor starts collecting in the vitreous cavity. 

Signs:

  • High intraocular pressure (IOP) and absent bleb.
  • Negative Seidel test.
  • Shallow anterior chamber (AC)

Treatment:

  • Initial treatment is with cycloplegics (atropine 1%) to dilate the ciliary ring and push the vitreous-lens-iris posteriorly.
  • Subsequent treatment if medical therapy fails is with Nd:YAG laser hyaloidotomy.
  • Pars plana vitrectomy can be considered in conditions that don't respond to the above treatment modalities.

questions.text: A young patient presents with loss of central vision. There is a family history of a similar condition. Both EOG and ERG are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given scenario is Stargardt's disease.

Stargardt's disease also known as Stargardt macular dystrophy or fundus flavimaculatus is the most common macular dystrophy. It most commonly is inherited in an autosomal-recessive manner caused by a mutation on an adenosine triphosphate-binding cassette (ABCA4) gene.

Characterized by macular "pisciform" flecks that accumulate at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), sometimes resulting in central macular atrophy early in life. Patients develop a macula with a “beaten bronze” appearance caused by atrophic changes in the RPE. In addition, a "dark" or "silent" choroid is seen on the fluorescein angiography that appears as a prominent retinal circulation against hypofluorescent choroid. 

The electroretinogram (ERG) and electro-oculography (EOG) are normal early in the disease but may be reduced in more advanced cases. Of note, the ERG findings do not directly correlate with clinical findings.

There is no known proven treatment for this disease. Because ABCA4 plays a role in vitamin A processing in the visual cycle, additional vitamin A is suspected to make the disease worse.

The image below shows macular pisciform flecks.

Other options: 

Option A: Retinitis pigmentosa: abnormal electroretinogram (ERG).

Option B: Rod–cone dystrophy: abnormal ERG.

Option D: Best's disease: Normal ERG with abnormal electrooculogram (EOG).

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with 6/6 vision in the right eye and vision for only hand movements in the left eye. On fundoscopy, the right eye appears normal. The left eye shows retinal detachment, subretinal yellowish exudates, and telangiectatic vessels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Unilateral decreased vision with retinal detachment, subretinal yellowish exudates and telangiectatic vessels in a young boy points to the diagnosis of Coats' disease.

Coats’ disease, described by Coats in 1908, affects boys three times more often than girls, has no reported racial or ethnic predilection, and is usually unilateral. The average age at diagnosis is 8–16 years. The clinical course is generally progressive. 

It is characterized by discrete zones of retinal vascular abnormalities like aneurysmal dilatation and leakage. It is associated with localized lipid deposition (hard exudates) and varying degrees of subretinal exudates. Vessels may appear telangiectatic, and they may have aneurysms that are grape-like, clustered, or light bulb-shaped. 

The image below depicts the typical vascular abnormalities with aneurysmal dilatation, telangiectasia, exudation, and severe lipid deposition in the macula which are seen in Coat's disease.

questions.text: What is a reverse hypopyon?

choices.text: Collection of pus in the vitreous
Collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber

questions.solution:
Reverse hypopyon is the collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber.

Silicone oil is the vitreous substitute that is injected into the vitreous cavity after vitrectomy. When it gets emulsified, it enters the anterior chamber and collects in the upper part.

Complications of silicone oil in the anterior chamber:

  1. Glaucoma
  2. Band-shaped keratopathy

The image below shows reverse hypopyon.

questions.text: Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism?
questions.solution:
Among the above options, -1.00 DC × 180 degrees is the correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism (SMA). 

There are 3 components for prescription of glasses.

1. The first number is the refractive power of the spherical component. It is represented as convex (+) or concave (-) dioptre sphere (DS).

2. The second number denotes the power of the cylinder, represented as convex (+) or concave (-) dioptre cylinder (DC).

3. The above two components are followed by an x representing the axis (orientation) of the cylinder.

In the most common type of SMA - with-the-rule astigmatism - meridian A (represented by 90 degrees) is more curved than meridian B (represented by 180 degrees). The light rays refracting from B focus on the retina, whereas those refracting from A focus in front of the retina. 

To correct this error, a negative cylindrical lens (DC) is used to focus the myopic rays of meridian A on the retina. This correction needs to occur at 90 degrees (meridian A). The axis of a cylindrical lens is perpendicular to the required correction and thus, the spectacles will have an axis of 180 degrees.

There is no spherical refractive error since the light rays from meridian B lies on the retina. Thus DS is 0.

questions.text: You can use a stenopaeic slit for all of the following except ____________.

choices.text: To find out the axis in astigmatism

questions.solution:
Stenopaeic slit is not used for corneal tattooing.

Stenopaeic slit is an ophthalmological instrument that is used in:

  • Fincham’s test (Option A) : This test is used to differentiate between the colored halos due to immature cataract and corneal abnormalities such as corneal edema due to glaucoma. 
  • To find out the axis in astigmatism (option D) for prescribing the correction glasses.
  • To find out the optimal site for optical iridectomy (option C) for treating cases of central macular or leucomatous corneal opacities.

Corneal tattooing was done mainly in the past for cosmetic purposes. It is commonly done for firm scars of corneal opacities in a eye without any useful vision.

The below given image is of stenopaeic slit.

Related Pearl: Fincham’s Test

Also called Emsley–Fincham Test

It used for differentiating between the colored halos due to cataract (lenticular) and those in corneal edema due to glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos.

Halos are broken up into segments which revolve as the slit moves → Lenticular halo

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo

The image shows a stenopaeic slit.

It causes reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit and no change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it. So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

questions.text: A 34-year-old lady comes to the clinic complaining of problems in her vision. On perimetry, a visual field defect as shown below is obtained. Which of the following vessels does not supply the anatomical location of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The image shows bitemporal hemianopia, a defect caused by optic chiasmal lesions. The middle cerebral artery does not supply the optic chiasma.

Blood supply of optic chiasma:

  • Anterior cerebral artery - dorsal chiasma
  • Anterior communicating artery - ventral chiasma
  • Internal carotid artery - ventral chiasma
  • Superior hypophyseal artery - ventral (branch of internal carotid artery).

questions.text: Identify the clinical condition.
questions.solution:
The image shows plexiform neurofibroma of the upper lid causing an S-shaped deformity of the upper lid and mechanical ptosis. This is seen particularly in neurofibromatosis type 1.

NF1 is caused by the autosomal dominant loss-of-function mutations in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17. It is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes neurofibromin, a negative RAS regulator. The disease is clinically diagnosed when any two of the following seven features are present:

  • Six or more café-au-lait macules (CALMs) - They are the hallmark of neurofibromatosis and are present in almost 100% of patients. They are present at birth but increase in size, number, and pigmentation, especially during the first few years of life, and are scattered over the entire body. 
  • Axillary or inguinal freckling
  • Two or more iris Lisch nodules - They are iris hamartomas that are best identified by a slit-lamp examination. They are present in the majority of patients with NF1.
  • Two or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma
  • A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoid dysplasia or cortical thinning of long bones such as the tibia
  • Optic gliomas (most frequently observed CNS tumor in NF1)
  • A first-degree relative with NF-1

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a painful decrease in vision of his right eye for the past 3 days. He underwent right phacoemulsification with PC-IOL insertion 6 months ago. Examination revealed a mild granulomatous anterior uveitis with minimal hypopyon and mild vitritis. There is a white plaque seen on the posterior lens capsule. Which one of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this condition?

choices.text: Vitrectomy and intravitreal injection of amphotericin B
Vitrectomy, removal of the IOL, and intravitreal injection of gentamicin
Vitrectomy, posterior capsulotomy, and intravitreal injection of vancomycin

questions.solution:
Painful decrease in vision following cataract surgery 6 months ago with granulomatous anterior uveitis, hypopyon, vitritis and a white plaque on the posterior lens capsule suggests a diagnosis of delayed-onset postoperative endophthalmitis caused by Propionibacterium acnes. The best management for the above clinical scenario would be vitrectomy and posterior capsulotomy, followed by intravitreal injection of vancomycin.

Delayed-onset endophthalmitis, a complication of cataract surgery, has a slow course and panuveitis like picture. There is low grade anterior chamber inflammation and vitritis. When caused by P. acnes, it typically presents from 3 months to 2 years after surgery with a characteristic white retro-lenticular plaque on the posterior capsule of lens. Endophthalmitis caused by Candida occurs within 3 months of surgery. 

Management includes anterior vitrectomy, IOL explantation, posterior capsulectomy, intravitreal vancomycin, and a scleral-fixated intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with red-eye, ocular pain, and acute loss of vision to the casualty. On fundoscopy, areas of retinal ischemia and necrosis were seen, leading to a diagnosis of acute retinal necrosis. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is seen in immunocompetent individuals.
Posterior pole is involved initially with centrifugal spread.
It may lead to retinal detachment.

questions.solution:
In acute retinal necrosis, the posterior pole is typically spared until late.

Acute retinal necrosis (ARN) occurs in immunocompetent individuals. It is a severe posterior uveitis causing retinal necrosis. Herpes zoster ophthalmicus is the most common cause of acute retinal necrosis in adults. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) and herpes simplex virus (HSV) are the commonest causes of acute retinal necrosis in children.

Patients present with confluent peripheral necrotizing retinitis, retinal arteritis with vaso-occlusion, and vitritis. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachments are common due to retinal thinning from large areas of necrosis. The posterior pole is involved only in the later stages.

Aciclovir is administered intravenously (10 mg/kg, every 8 hours) for 10–14 days, and then orally (800 mg, five times daily) for 6–12 weeks. Oral valaciclovir or famciclovir may be substituted for oral aciclovir, with similar outcomes but better tolerability. Intravitreal ganciclovir or foscarnet may enhance the prognosis. Systemic steroids may be started 24 hours after the initiation of antiviral therapy, especially in severe cases. Laser retinopexy is performed around necrotic areas.

Progressive outer retinal necrosis is a manifestation of HSV or varicella zoster virus (VZV) that occurs in immunocompromised individuals. It may begin at the posterior pole or the periphery. It has a rapid course and is not generally associated with vasculitis.

questions.text: An elderly patient admitted with multiple comorbidities in the ICU, developed exposure keratitis and ulceration. An ophthalmology opinion was sought. Incidentally, on fundoscopy, the resident found the following picture. What is this most likely due to?
questions.solution:
The given image suggests a diagnosis of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The hallmark of Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is neovascularization. Abnormal new vessel formation, which occurs on the inner (vitreous) surface of the retina and may extend into the vitreous cavity, can cause vitreous haemorrhage. Neovascularization is often accompanied by pre-retinal fibrous tissue, which, along with the vitreous, can contract, resulting in traction retinal detachment. In addition, tiny microaneurysms can also be seen.

questions.text: A preterm neonate admitted to NICU who received supplemental oxygen is being screened for retinopathy of prematurity. Fundus examination reveals a subtotal retinal detachment. How will you stage the disease?
questions.solution:
Subtotal retinal detachment is considered to be stage 4 of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). 

The clinical staging of ROP is as follows:

  • Stage 1 - Formation of a demarcation line at the edge of vessels, dividing the vascular from the avascular retina.
  • Stage 2- Formation of an intraretinal ridge 
  • Stage 3- Ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous
  • Stage 4- Subtotal retinal detachment
  • Stage 5- Total retinal detachment

questions.text: A slit-lamp examination reveals the following finding. It is also noted that these yellow-white vitreous opacities do not settle down when the eye is immobile. All of the following statements about this condition are true except:
questions.solution:
The examination findings are suggestive of asteroid bodies/hyalosis. It is not common in myopes.

Asteroid hyalosis is a common degenerative process in which calcium pyrophosphate particles collect within the vitreous gel. It is seen clinically as numerous tiny round yellow-white opacities of varying size and density. These move with the vitreous during eye movements but do not sediment inferiorly when the eye is immobile.

Only one eye is affected in 75% of patients; it rarely causes visual problems and the majority of patients are asymptomatic. The cause of asteroid hyalosis is unknown, but it has been associated with diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. The prevalence of asteroid hyalosis increases with age and affects 3% of those aged 75–86 years. It is more common in men than in women. While treatment of asteroid hyalosis is usually unnecessary, vitrectomy may occasionally be indicated.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment option in advanced keratoconus?
questions.solution:
Vision correction with spectacles with spherical/toric soft contact lenses is suboptimal and only applicable to the early stages of keratoconus, not in the advanced stages.

Keratoconus is a progressive, non-inflammatory, bilateral corneal ectasia characterized by cone-like steepening due to irregular stromal thinning. This leads to a conical corneal protrusion, significant vision loss, myopia and irregular astigmatism. 

The available options for the management of keratoconus are highly dependent on the stage of the disease and its progression. If the disease is stabilized (no progression), the emphasis is given to correcting the vision. If the disease is progressing, the emphasis is on slowing (arresting) the progression.

Treatment options in moderate-to-advanced keratoconus:

  • Rigid gas-permeable contact lenses and vaulting scleral lenses are the mainstays of vision treatment for moderate to advanced KCN. Their main advantage is the creation of a tear pool between the lens and the cornea, which naturally neutralizes the ocular aberrations associated with keratoconus. (Option B and C)
  • Intra-corneal ring segments (INTACS)- small curved PMMA ring or set of rings that are implanted in the cornea to help flatten corneal curvature to improve vision.
  • Corneal transplantation- Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty (DALK) and penetrating keratoplasty (PKP)

Corneal collagen cross-linking with riboflavin (CXL or C3R) and ultraviolet-A rays arrest the progression of the disease. (Option D)

 

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

questions.text: Which among the following is normal astigmatism seen in eyes due to the pressure of the eyelids?
questions.solution:
With-the-rule astigmatism is normally seen in the eyes due to the pressure of the eyelids.

In with-the-rule astigmatism, the vertical meridian is more curved. This is more common and often occurs due to the pressure of eyelids on the eye. In against-the-rule astigmatism (ATR) (option B), the horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian. In both these types, the principal meridia are vertical and horizontal (90 and 180 degrees) and are at right angles to each other. 

The other types of astigmatism include oblique and bi-oblique astigmatism. In oblique astigmatism (option C), the two principal meridians are not the horizontal and vertical meridians, although they are at right angles to each other. In bi-oblique astigmatism (option D), the two principal meridians are not at right angles to each other; for example, one may be at 40 degrees and the other, at 100 degrees.

questions.text: What is the most common malignant tumor of the eyelid?
questions.solution:
Basal cell carcinoma constitutes 85–90% of all malignant epithelial eyelid tumors. It is locally malignant and most commonly involves the lower lid, followed by the medial canthus, upper lid, and outer canthus.

Type Common location Clinical features Spread
Basal cell carcinoma Lower lid/Medial canthus
  • Nodule
  • Central ulceration with pearly surface, telangiectasia
 local
Squamous cell carcinoma Lower lid, from previous actinic keratosis
  • Ulcer with thickened margins, keratosis
  • papillomatous

Local, lymph nodes
Sebaceous cell carcinoma Upper lid
  • Nodule-like chalazion
  • Multifocal
  • Females >males
  • Recurrences common

Local intraepithelial lymph nodes
Malignant melanoma Previous nevi
  • >6 mm pigmented, 
  • Vascularization
  • inflammation

Local, vascular lymph nodes

questions.text: A woman comes to the ophthalmology OPD because of having vision difficulties for the last 3 months. On fundoscopic examination, the following findings are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a fundus typical of pathological myopia due to the stretching of the retina.

The tigroid appearance or tessellated appearance of the fundus can be appreciated. As the eye enlarges, the retinal pigment epithelium becomes thinner, resulting in:

  • A tessellated (checkered) appearance of the fundus
  • Increased visibility of the choroidal vasculature

Other features of the myopic fundus are as follows:

  • Lacquer cracks are spontaneous ruptures of the elastic lamina of Bruch’s membrane. It appears yellowish-white. it is usually located in the posterior pole.
  • Annular gray shadow around the optic disc
  • Lattice degeneration
  • Foster Fuchs spots
  • Cystoid degeneration
  • Total retinal atrophy
